Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CDI-Type II: 4 Dimensional Visualization of Past Ocean Circulation from Paleoceanographic Data
Award.AbstractNarration: One of the fundamental challenges in the study of past climate change in Earth history is how to reconstruct and compare past ocean circulation (as derived from sparse geochemical data collected from fossils in deep-sea sedimentary cores) with modern ocean circulation (as constructed from modern oceanographic observations and computer simulations) to yield insight into the differences and processes governing ocean circulation throughout the last glacial cycle from 150,000 years ago to the present. Similarly, a major challenge in computer science is how to extract information from sparse datasets, and how to effectively combine computational thinking with automated data analysis, to extract new knowledge about features and processes. Our multidisciplinary and multi-institutional project brings together a team of computer scientists, physical oceanographers, paleoceanographers, and computational geophysicists to address these challenges. We are developing an innovative suite of computational tools to explore past changes in global ocean circulation by allowing researchers to interact with data in a 3-dimensional environment across a geologically relevant time domain (the 4th dimension). This project will merge analysis of ocean flow with 40 years of previously-collected geochemical data from deep-sea sedimentary cores in order to gain new insights into past ocean circulation change. Our research will take advantage of the unique analytical resources and interdisciplinary collaborative environment provided by the UC Davis KeckCAVES (W.M. Keck Center for Active Visualization in the Earth Sciences). The KeckCAVES provides immersive interactive visualization technologies that help scientists identify meaningful patterns in complex datasets. In this unique collaborative environment, we are developing methods to improve data interpolation, to extract ocean flow patterns, and to characterize ocean flow over time for potential change detection, along with interactive means of visualizing and interacting with those large and time-dependent datasets. The computational methods developed in this project are adaptable to a wide range of visualization and data-analysis applications for analysis of flow fields. The scientific visualization methods we develop will be used to develop innovative, provocative, and intuitive instructional materials for undergraduate and graduate education; for making other researchers familiar with new scientific methodology (visually-aided analysis); for bringing science and scientific results to the public; and for bringing interactive scientific visualization technology to all of the partner institutions in this collaborative project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the end of the last Ice Age, about 20,000 years ago, the atmosphere held about one-third less carbon dioxide than the year A.D. 1800 (before the Industrial Revolution). As the great ice sheets melted, the atmospheric concentration increased from 190 ppm (parts per million) to 270 ppm in less than 10,000 years. Most of this increase was caused by transfer of carbon dioxide from the ocean to the atmosphere. To better understand the ocean processes responsible for the release of carbon from the ocean, this research project compiled hundreds of deep-sea sediment core measurements that contain the signal of the chemistry of the past ocean. The new compilation includes carbon isotope records that are a measure of the ratio of two different stable isotopes of carbon (with atomic masses of 12 and 13), which is affected by the conversion of carbon between inorganic and organic forms. Thus, it provides information about carbon cycling; it is also often used as a tracer for the circulation of deep water through the ocean.
Here we used this information to reconstruct the state of ocean circulation and ocean carbon storage before, during, and after this climate transition.

Because the ocean and its circulation have a complex three-dimensional geometry, another important accomplishment of this project was to develop techniques for visualizing the carbon isotope data in three-dimensions and finding ways to infer the properties of the ocean throughout its entire volume. This was a challenging task given that the data available from the past are almost exclusively telling us about conditions at the seafloor, because the data are derived from the calcium carbonate shells of organisms which live on the seafloor. This project has developed a novel method that uses the physical principles of the movement of seawater in order to fill in the missing information between the data points. With this method, the current best estimate of the three-dimensional properties of the ocean at the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM, 20,000 years ago) were produced. Now we have obtained a geographically complete picture of the temperature and carbon distributions of the glacial ocean, a necessary step to understand the heat and carbon budgets that set the global climate. In addition, we have connected the climate of the glacial planet to the modern-day by reconstructing the changing ocean from the LGM to today. In order to test the fidelity of our products, we have produced multiple LGM scenarios under different assumptions and documented the characteristics that are robust and those that are not.

This project was atypical in that we assembled a interdisciplinary team with equal representation from oceanographers and computer scientists. All of the ocean reconstructions mentioned above have been quality controlled and translated into a data format for use with visualization software developed by the UC Davis KeckCAVES team. This software runs in a visualization cave at UC Davis, but has also been ported to a 3D television in Woods Hole that provides the proof-of-concept that such visualization techniques can be implemented by scientists, students, and educational facilities across the world. Toward the scientific goals of this project, the visualization tools have led to improved methods of data interpolation, automatic extraction of flow patterns, and change detection in the ocean circulation. The new ability to be immersed in a four dimensional (three spatial dimensions and time) reconstruction of the ocean circulation has illuminated new explanations for the changing climate of the Earth's not-too-distant past.
